captions.text:
Oh blimey, you know it&#39;s that time of year,
don&#39;t you.

When the triple-As all go into hibernation
and all the games the publishers were a little
bit nervous about come out in bloom.

Hence all that Agony business, I suppose,
which publishers probably would be nervous

about if they were planning to make eye contact
with their mothers anytime soon.

And if I were a publisher I&#39;d be a bit nervous
about Vampyr, I&#39;d be all like &quot;Do you mind

if I run it past a proof reader, &#39;cos I&#39;m
pretty sure you spelt it wrong.&quot;

You spelt it right everywhere else, I&#39;m just
worried having the title like that might make

us look slightly pretentious, like spelling
Magic with a K, or sticking an E on the end
of Noir.

Vampyr comes to us from French developer Dontnod
Entertainment, and before you say anything,

yes, I looked it up and the French don&#39;t spell
Vampire that way either, so who the fuck knows.

Dontnod were previously responsible for Remember
Me and Life Is Strange, and as such Vampyr

carries the distinction of being their first
game whose title isn&#39;t a complete sentence.

Vampyr is a gothic action RPG with a wide
open world in the Deus Ex sense of not being

particularly wide or open, taking place in
a sort of Legoland version of early 20th century
Lan-dan tahn.

The protagonist is Jonathan Reid, a tall dark
pasty bloke with a pointy beard whose transformation

into a vampire therefore couldn&#39;t have come
fast enough.
Erm, excuse me, Yahtzee, they&#39;re called Ekons.
I beg your pardon?
Ekons!
It&#39;s our special word for vampires.
We made it up.
I can fucking tell you did.

Might stick with vampire if it&#39;s all the same
to you, Ekons sounds too much like an alien
race of the week from Doctor Who.

Anyway, Jonathan&#39;s a physician by trade and
returns after the first world war to find

London stricken by both the Spanish Flu and
a plague of ghouls, who - not ghouls, Yahtzee,
Skals.
What&#39;s a fucking Skal?
It&#39;s a human tainted by vampire blood!
THAT&#39;S A GHOUL!
WE CALL IT A SKAL!
Don&#39;t do this to me again, Dontnod.

I couldn&#39;t understand a fucking word of Life
Is Strange &#39;cos everyone was speaking in this

weird French interpretation of how young people
talk.

Anyway, now we get to the other reason publishers
might be a bit nervous about Vampyr: because

it&#39;s trying to do something innovative, a
surefire way to make a publisher shrink back

holding up a crucifix and sucking on a preorder
bonus for comfort.

The rub is, each district has a number of
named characters we can talk to and do sidequests

for, and as a physician it&#39;s Jonathan&#39;s responsibility
to get to know them and craft them the right
medicine when they&#39;re ill.

It&#39;s not hard, 90% of the time they need &#39;Fatigue&#39;
medicine which I&#39;m pretty sure is just Red
bull.

Unfortunately Jonathan is a vampire on top
of being a doctor, so he also has to decide

which members of his social circle he&#39;s going
to rip open and chug like a wild cherry Capri-sun.

With the understanding that their disappearance
will have knock-on effects on other characters

and the health of the district as a whole
as well as your digestion.

Now, that sounds interesting, doesn&#39;t it,
especially since the value of a target&#39;s blood

goes up the more you&#39;ve gotten to know them,
organically pushing us to get fully invested

in a character&#39;s backstory and struggles before
we put them in a sandwich.

So, and here I find myself flashing back to
my review of Remember Me, that was the good
idea, here&#39;s how they fuck it up.

I probably made it sound like you HAVE to
pick people to kill, didn&#39;t I, much as the
game does, but the thing is, you really don&#39;t.

Your reward for chowing on your chums is a
big dose of XP for buying vampire powers and

stat upgrades (or perhaps I should say, Lestat
upgrades, hmuh hmuh hmuh), but you also get

XP from basic combat and achieving objectives
and after a whole game of not killing a single

citizen I was, at worst, slightly underlevelled,
and none of the boss fights were insurmountable
once I had the patterns down.

See, I went for the pacifist run because there
was a distinct whiff of moral choice-driven

story branching about all this and my instinct
is always to shoot for best ending because

it&#39;s usually the one that feels like an ending
and not like I fucked something up.
Vampyr may be an exception, however.

It really wants to be a story about a broody
vampire tortured by the clash between his

urge to kill and his duty to heal, but after
I didn&#39;t kill anyone, it becomes a story about

a perfectly nice if slightly intense bloke
who doesn&#39;t get enough vitamin D. So the quote
&quot;good&quot; ending was a bit of a damp squib.

One of Reid&#39;s vampire pal&#39;s trying to get
their melodrama on going &quot;Ooh we are nothing

more than killers and our blood is cursed&quot;
and Reid&#39;s all like &quot;Bollocks we are, I haven&#39;t
killed shit.&quot;

&quot;Oh, so you haven&#39;t, never mind then, let&#39;s
get McDonalds.&quot;

Now, when Reid says he hasn&#39;t killed shit,
he is truncating a little, he should have

said &quot;I haven&#39;t killed shit except for the
five hundred thousand vampire hunters I murdered
in standard combat.&quot;

Yes, this is the rather glaring incongruity
of Vampyr.

There&#39;s something a little bit hollow about
Jonathan Reid&#39;s quiet nobility and pacifism

when he&#39;s just had to murder twelve identical
cockney thugs on the way back from the chemist.

Well, I suppose it&#39;s self-defense killing,
but it still raises a lot of questions.

How come killing these lads by the hundred
somehow doesn&#39;t affect the rest of London&#39;s

population like killing named characters does,
did they all get bussed in from Wolverhampton?

Also, if Reid can drink blood from his enemies
mid-combat in a way that doesn&#39;t kill them,

why can&#39;t he figure out a way to nonlethally
drink blood from his mates as well?
A little please and thankyou goes a long way.

We do need there to be combat because otherwise
there&#39;s no core gameplay loop and more to

the point it&#39;d be fucking boring, so maybe
we could&#39;ve just fought ghouls?
Sorry, Skals.

But if we did that, it would raise the question
of why all the named characters are obliviously

going about their cheerful cockney lives when
there&#39;s a fucking zombie apocalypse going
on next door.

Also, since we&#39;re suggesting changes, did
you ever consider making the combat less shitty?

It&#39;s Dark Soulsy stamina management mixed
with a bit of Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines
combat, ergo, shittiness.

There&#39;s a very small variety of monsters and
weapons and your vampiric powers aren&#39;t that
great.

They&#39;re not much fun to use or even as effective
as just twatting the dudes with one of the

stronger weapons, and I&#39;ll remind you we&#39;re
supposed to like these powers so much we&#39;d
murder our friends to improve them.

The problem with the core dilemma of Vampyr,
kill friends to get XP to make combat easier,

is that it falls apart if, like me, you enjoy
a challenge and removing it doesn&#39;t feel like
a reward.

And the other problem is with the other half
of the concept - interacting with characters,

exclusively done through fucking dialogue
trees of the worst kind.
Tell me more about the city.
Tell me more about your job.

Tell me more about that thing you said about
the city that I&#39;m awkwardly bringing up again
apropos of nothing.

Tell me more about this weird boggle-eyed
look we&#39;re giving each other like a pair of
lovestruck goldfish in neighbouring bowls.

They even routinely interrupt important plot
cutscenes so that Reid can run down a questions
list.

Even in the very last cutscene just as everyone&#39;s
poised for the climax.

I&#39;m sorry, but if you&#39;re still giving us exposition
dumps literal seconds before the dramatic
conclusion, something&#39;s gone wrong.

It bears about as much resemblance to natural
conversation as sticking your knob in a Muller

fruit corner does to a whirlwind love affair
and it makes all the participants come across
as incredibly stiff.
Well they are British, Yahtzee.
Oh ho!
A cheeky sting!
Scurry off, you rummy blighter.
Fish and chips.
